original_title: Sri Lanka shares muted on fears of debt restructuring, long weekend
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s stocks closed lower on Thursday, as investors held back due to the long weekend, causing the index to fall, according to an analyst.
The All Share Price Index (ASPI) was down 0.90 percent or 82.93 points to 9,256.90.
“The market is muted mainly due to the upcoming long weekend,” the analyst said.
“With that, fears of potential local debt restructuring have also returned, and investors are waiting for more clarity.”

The concerns resurfaced after Central Bank Governor Nandala Weerasinghe said that Sri Lanka will not restructure Treasury bills outside of central bank holdings and will engage with major T-bond holders for voluntary “optimization”.

“There will be some treatment on central bank-held Treasury bills, and other Treasury bill holdings will not be treated. Treasury bonds, we envisage voluntary optimization,” Governor Weerasinghe told a creditor presentation on March 30.
Some domestic debt restructuring discussions have been scheduled for April 20, and investors are likely to wait for further clarity before investing.
The most liquid index, S&P SL20, closed up 0.81 percent or 21.64 points to 2,685.91.
Top gainers were Vallibel Finance, Sampath Bank, and Sri Lanka Telecom.

The Board of Directors of Sri Lanka Telecom PLC (SLT) and Lanka Hospitals PLC announced that the Cabinet of Ministers has granted approval in principle for the divestment of the stakes held by the Treasury Secretary in the two companies.
The market saw a net foreign inflow of 66 million rupees, and the total offshore outflows recorded so far in 2023 are 2.8 billion rupees. (Colombo/Apr06/2023)
